docs.abstract: A federal judge has dismissed a suit brought by the city that would have forced fossil fuel companies to pay for some costs of climate change.
docs.snippet: A federal judge has dismissed a suit brought by the city that would have forced fossil fuel companies to pay for some costs of climate change.
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge has rejected New York City’s lawsuit to make fossil fuel companies help pay the costs of dealing with climate change.

headline.main: Judge Throws Out New York Climate Lawsuit

docs.abstract: An agreement on the Caspian Sea’s status resolves one problem in an oil region with many of them.
docs.snippet: An agreement on the Caspian Sea’s status resolves one problem in an oil region with many of them.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the years, a single oil venture in the Caspian Sea owned by ExxonMobil and other majors stumbled through so many cost overruns and technical problems it gained an unfortunate nickname: the “Cash-all-gone” field.

headline.main: In a Prize for Big Oil Firms, Caspian Deal Eases Access
headline.print_headline: A deal restores some order at the Caspian Sea

docs.abstract: This week: a surprising contribution to climate science from the 19th century, a quick E.P.A. update, and a trove of Shell documents.
docs.snippet: This week: a surprising contribution to climate science from the 19th century, a quick E.P.A. update, and a trove of Shell documents.
docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline.main: Taking a Leaf Out of Thoreau’s Book

byline.original: By Brad Plumer and John Schwartz

docs.abstract: The case, involving Exxon Mobil’s climate change accounting, could renew interest in a congressional push to curb state regulatory powers.
docs.snippet: The case, involving Exxon Mobil’s climate change accounting, could renew interest in a congressional push to curb state regulatory powers.
docs.lead_paragraph: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________

headline.main: Could New York’s Suit Against Exxon Help Undermine the Law Behind It?

docs.abstract: A New York State lawsuit charges that the oil giant has not properly accounted for the climate risks at the core of its business.
docs.snippet: A New York State lawsuit charges that the oil giant has not properly accounted for the climate risks at the core of its business.
docs.lead_paragraph: In August, a lawyer for Exxon Mobil told a state court in Manhattan that New York’s attorney general should either sue the company for misleading investors about the impact of climate change on its finances or drop the case. “They should put up or shut up,” the lawyer, Theodore Wells Jr., said of a tangled case that had dragged on for more than two years. The weary judge, Barry Ostrager, agreed. “This cannot go on interminably,” he said.

docs.abstract: Francis, a vocal supporter of the Paris climate accord, summoned leaders from the world’s biggest oil companies to urge a transition from fossil fuels.
docs.snippet: Francis, a vocal supporter of the Paris climate accord, summoned leaders from the world’s biggest oil companies to urge a transition from fossil fuels.
docs.lead_paragraph: ROME — Three years ago, Pope Francis issued a sweeping letter that highlighted the global crisis posed by climate change and called for swift action to save the environment and the planet.

headline.main: Pope Tells Oil Executives to Act on Climate: ‘There Is No Time to Lose’
headline.print_headline: Pope Urges Oil Executives to Act on Climate: ‘There Is No Time to Lose’

docs.abstract: We’re part of a bipartisan group urging Congress to put a fee on carbon-dioxide emissions and return the revenue to American taxpayers.
docs.snippet: We’re part of a bipartisan group urging Congress to put a fee on carbon-dioxide emissions and return the revenue to American taxpayers.
docs.lead_paragraph: As former leaders of our parties in the United States Senate, we know what it takes to achieve a bipartisan breakthrough in Congress. For all the talk of discord in Washington, we see the possibility of finding common ground on a divisive issue. As surprising as it may sound, climate change offers a chance for both parties to come together and deliver a victory — and cash dividends — to the American people.

headline.main: Here’s How to Break the Impasse on Climate

byline.original: By Trent Lott and John Breaux

docs.abstract: Given new veto power over the tax breaks the state lavishes on industry, local officials are starting to say their budget needs come first. Business leaders are aghast.
docs.snippet: Given new veto power over the tax breaks the state lavishes on industry, local officials are starting to say their budget needs come first. Business leaders are aghast.
docs.lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — It was a squabble over $2.9 million in property-tax breaks — small change for Exxon Mobil, a company that measures its earnings by the billions.

headline.main: A School Board Says No to Big Oil, and Alarms Sound in Business-Friendly Louisiana
headline.print_headline: Daring to Say No to Big Oil

docs.abstract: Ms. Harris opened an investigation of the oil giant as California’s attorney general, but critics quickly noted that no lawsuit had been filed.
docs.snippet: Ms. Harris opened an investigation of the oil giant as California’s attorney general, but critics quickly noted that no lawsuit had been filed.
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, researchers, activists and government officials have pointed to evidence that Exxon Mobil had in-depth knowledge of the risks of fossil fuels while misleading the public about the severity of climate change.

headline.main: ‘I Have Sued Exxon Mobil,’ Kamala Harris Said. Not Quite.

docs.abstract: Exxon, Marathon, BP and others are flaring natural gas, a wasteful practice with  consequences in the fight against climate change, at a record pace.
docs.snippet: Exxon, Marathon, BP and others are flaring natural gas, a wasteful practice with  consequences in the fight against climate change, at a record pace.
docs.lead_paragraph: When leaders from Exxon Mobil and BP gathered last month with other fossil-fuel executives to declare they were serious about climate change, they cited progress in curbing an energy-wasting practice called flaring — the intentional burning of natural gas as companies drill faster than pipelines can move the energy away.

headline.main: Despite Their Promises, Giant Energy Companies Burn Away Vast Amounts of Natural Gas
headline.print_headline: Gas Flaring on the Rise Even as Energy Giants Promise to Cut It Back
